Customers build applications using
AWS Lambda to be more agile

while taking advantage of built-in
security, scalability, and high availability

But, when your data-intensive applications require fast
access to large volumes of shared data,

the ephemeral nature of AWS Lambda functions (and their limit of
512 MB of local storage) can pose a challenge.

Without a persistent file store, your applications would need to
download your data from a separate object store or database,

process it, and then write any changes
back to the original source.

Amazon Elastic File System (EFS) solves this issue by
enabling your applications to access data directly,

without having to download it to local storage first! EFS is a highly
available, durable, serverless, set-and-forget elastic file system

that simplifies the sharing of data that must persist
beyond and between executions of AWS Lambda functions.
There’s no additional coding required to ensure data consistency.

When data changes, it’s immediately available
across separate AWS Lambda function invocations,

Amazon EC2 instances,
and your containers running on Amazon ECS.

And, you can configure your AWS Lambda functions to
access an EFS file system in a single step
via the AWS Management Console, CLI, or SDK.

The powerful combination of AWS Lambda and EFS
is ideal for loading large models,

libraries, and other reference data to allow
you to build serverless machine learning,
and other data-intensive applications.

You can also use AWS Lambda with EFS to
process and back up large amounts of data,
host web content, and developinternal build systems.
